biases.summary: You want to do something instead of nothing, even if doing nothing might be better.
biases.example: A coach makes a change to the team even if it might not help them win.

biases.summary: You like to add things to make something better, even if taking things away works better.
biases.example: Instead of removing bad parts of a story, you add more details.

biases.summary: Your feelings influence your decisions.
biases.example: You might like a product because it makes you feel good, not because it's the best.

biases.summary: You avoid choices when you don't know all the information.
biases.example: You might pick an investment with clear risks over one with unclear risks, even if it could pay more.

biases.summary: You rely too much on the first piece of information you hear.
biases.example: If someone first says a price is $100, you'll think a price of $80 is a good deal.

biases.summary: You notice things that you are already thinking about a lot.
biases.example: If you are worried about spiders, you might notice them more often.

biases.summary: You trust automated systems too much, even when they are wrong.
biases.example: A pilot might rely on a computer system even when their own senses tell them something is wrong.

biases.summary: You guess how likely something is based on how easily you can think of examples.
biases.example: You might think plane crashes are common because you see them on the news.

biases.summary: You spend too much time on small, unimportant details.
biases.example: A group might argue a lot about the color of a logo instead of the main plan.

biases.summary: You spend more money when using cards than when using cash.
biases.example: You might buy more things when paying with a credit card.

biases.summary: You stick to your past beliefs even when new facts show they are wrong.
biases.example: An investor might keep a stock that is losing money because they first thought it was good.

biases.summary: You don't think about the bigger picture when making a decision.
biases.example: You look at one piece of information without thinking about where it came from.

biases.summary: Things look different depending on what you just saw.
biases.example: After seeing cheap items, a normal-priced item might seem expensive.

biases.summary: Adding a third, worse option can make you prefer one of the other two.
biases.example: When choosing popcorn sizes, a medium option that's almost as expensive as a large can make the large seem better.

biases.summary: You tend to stick with the option that is automatically chosen for you.
biases.example: Many people don't change the settings on their new phone.

biases.summary: People argue more about small, unimportant things.
biases.example: A group might spend a lot of time debating a minor detail in a plan.

biases.summary: You are less likely to spend larger bills than the same amount in smaller bills.
biases.example: You might break a $20 bill before you are willing to spend the money.

biases.summary: Things seem more different when you compare them side-by-side.
biases.example: When looking at two job offers together, you might focus on small differences.

biases.summary: Investors sell stocks that are winning but keep stocks that are losing.
biases.example: Someone might quickly sell a stock that made a little money but hold onto one that is losing money.

biases.summary: You focus on one detail and ignore the bigger picture.
biases.example: A manager might only look at how one team is doing and not the whole company.

biases.summary: You avoid things that make you feel very scared, even if they are safe.
biases.example: You might avoid flying even though it's safer than driving.

biases.summary: You value things more if you put a lot of effort into them.
biases.example: You might think a piece of furniture you built is great even if it's not perfect.

biases.summary: You don't realize how much your feelings can change your future choices.
biases.example: You might say you won't eat a lot later when you are not hungry now.

biases.summary: You value things you own more than things you don't.
biases.example: You might want to sell your old toy for more money than you would pay for the same toy.

biases.summary: You put too much importance on one part of a situation.
biases.example: When thinking about moving to a sunny place, you might only think about the weather.

biases.summary: The way information is presented changes how you see it.
biases.example: People are more likely to agree to a surgery with a '90% survival rate' than a '10% death rate.'

biases.summary: You can only see objects being used in their usual way.
biases.example: You might not realize you can use a coin as a screwdriver in an emergency.

biases.summary: You think future pain will be worse than it really is.
biases.example: You might avoid a doctor's visit because you imagine the pain will be too bad.

biases.summary: You are more motivated when you are closer to your goal.
biases.example: You might work harder on a task when you see the finish line.

biases.summary: You don't understand how your feelings will affect you in the future.
biases.example: You might make plans for when you are upset that you wouldn't actually do.

biases.summary: You prefer small rewards now over bigger rewards later.
biases.example: You might choose to get a small amount of money today instead of a larger amount next week.

biases.summary: You like things more if you helped make them.
biases.example: You might like a piece of furniture you built more than one you bought already made.

biases.summary: You think you have more control over things than you really do.
biases.example: You might think you can make a traffic light change by pressing the button many times.

biases.summary: You think your feelings about future events will be stronger and last longer.
biases.example: You might think you will be very sad for a long time after something bad happens.

biases.summary: Rewards can make you do things.
biases.example: A company might give bonuses to workers who do a good job.

biases.summary: Your body's feelings, like hunger, can affect your judgments.
biases.example: A judge might give a lighter sentence if they are not hungry.

biases.summary: You keep putting more into something even when it's not working.
biases.example: You might keep spending money on a broken car to fix it even if it would be cheaper to buy a new one.

biases.summary: You use the same tool for every problem.
biases.example: If you only have a hammer, you might try to fix everything by hammering.

biases.summary: You might prefer a smaller, better thing over a larger, worse thing when they are shown separately.
biases.example: You might pay more for a small scoop of great ice cream than a big scoop of okay ice cream if you see them alone.

biases.summary: You can only focus on so much at once.
biases.example: You might miss something happening around you if you are focused on your phone.

biases.summary: You hate losing things more than you like gaining things.
biases.example: You might feel worse about losing $10 than you would feel good about finding $10.

biases.summary: You are more excited by rewards when you don't know exactly what you will get.
biases.example: You might be more interested in a game with mystery prizes.

biases.summary: You spread resources evenly instead of focusing on the best options.
biases.example: You might invest a little bit of money in many different things instead of the few best ones.

biases.summary: You like brands that care about social issues.
biases.example: You might choose a coffee brand that is known for fair trade.

biases.summary: You switch between choices even when it makes things worse.
biases.example: You might keep changing your mind about something even if it leads to bad results.

biases.summary: You think doing something harmful is worse than not doing something that causes harm.
biases.example: You might feel worse about lying than about not telling the whole truth.

biases.summary: You ignore bad news.
biases.example: An investor might avoid looking at their stocks when the market is down.

biases.summary: You judge a decision based on the result, not how good the decision was at the time.
biases.example: You might think a past decision was bad just because it had a bad outcome.

biases.summary: Rewards can make you like something less.
biases.example: A child who loves to draw might stop liking it if they get a reward every time.

biases.summary: Safety rules can make people take more risks.
biases.example: People might drive faster if they are wearing seatbelts.

biases.summary: Where things are placed can affect what you choose.
biases.example: You are more likely to buy things that are at eye level in a store.

biases.summary: You stick to a plan even when it's clearly not working.
biases.example: A project might keep going even with problems because the team doesn't want to change the plan.

biases.summary: You think tasks will take less time than they really will.
biases.example: You might always think you can finish a project faster than you actually can.

biases.summary: After buying something expensive, you ignore its flaws.
biases.example: After buying a fancy car, you might not want to admit it has problems.

biases.summary: You prefer rewards now over rewards in the future.
biases.example: You might choose to have fun now instead of saving for later.

biases.summary: You focus more on avoiding bad things than on making good things happen.
biases.example: A government might spend more money on stopping crime than on improving education.

biases.summary: You make choices based on potential gains and losses, and you dislike losses more.
biases.example: You might take a safe option to avoid losing money even if a riskier option could give you more.

biases.summary: You prefer choices that seem certain.
biases.example: You might prefer a discount that gives you a sure amount off over one with a chance of a bigger discount.

biases.summary: You do the opposite of what you are told if you feel forced.
biases.example: A child might do something they were told not to do just to show they can.

biases.summary: You avoid making choices that could lead to regret.
biases.example: You might stick with a safe investment to avoid the chance of losing money.

biases.summary: You think you have more self-control than you actually do.
biases.example: Someone on a diet might think they can easily resist a treat.

biases.summary: You focus on things that stand out and miss other important things.
biases.example: You might remember a news story with a strong image more than one with important facts.

biases.summary: You think about the direct results of actions but not the later results.
biases.example: A new invention might make things easier now but cause problems later.

biases.summary: Things that appeal to more of your senses are more engaging.
biases.example: Food that looks, smells, and tastes good is more enjoyable.

biases.summary: You learn complex things by starting with small steps.
biases.example: You might train a dog to do a trick by rewarding small steps towards the full trick.

biases.summary: You prefer things to stay the same.
biases.example: You might not want to switch to a new phone even if it's better.

biases.summary: You look for things where it's easiest to see them.
biases.example: You might look for your keys under a streetlamp even if you didn't drop them there.

biases.summary: You keep doing something because you've already invested time or money in it.
biases.example: You might keep watching a bad movie because you already paid for it.

biases.summary: You focus on an easy-to-measure number instead of the real thing you want to measure.
biases.example: Judging how good employees are just by how many hours they work.

biases.summary: You do something you should do by pairing it with something you want to do.
biases.example: You might only watch your favorite show while you are exercising.

biases.summary: You underestimate how much time you save by going faster.
biases.example: You might not realize how little time you actually save by speeding.

biases.summary: You want to finish a whole thing.
biases.example: You might feel like you have to eat everything on your plate.

biases.summary: How much something changes needs to be big enough for you to notice.
biases.example: You might not notice a small change in the weight of something light.

biases.summary: You prefer to get rid of a small risk completely over reducing a bigger risk.
biases.example: You might spend a lot of time on a very small safety issue instead of a bigger one.

biases.summary: You think if one person gains something, someone else must lose.
biases.example: In a negotiation, you might think if the other person gets a good deal, you got a bad one.

biases.summary: You do things because other people are doing them.
biases.example: You might like a song just because it's popular.

biases.summary: You blame your actions on outside things but blame others' actions on their personality.
biases.example: You say you were late because of traffic, but your friend was late because they are not on time.

biases.summary: You give human traits to things that are not human.
biases.example: You talk to your pet like it understands everything you say.

biases.summary: You think other people are like you.
biases.example: If you like a certain hobby, you might think most people like it too.

biases.summary: You believe someone more if they seem like an expert, even if they are not.
biases.example: You might believe a famous person's opinion on something they don't really know about.

biases.summary: You like someone more after doing them a favor.
biases.example: You might start to like a coworker more after helping them with a task.

biases.summary: You think you are less biased than other people.
biases.example: You might see other people's biases but not your own.

biases.summary: People look better in a group than alone.
biases.example: A person in a group photo might seem more attractive.

biases.summary: You feel less empathy for many people in need than for one person.
biases.example: You might be less likely to donate to a large group than to help one person.

biases.summary: You say what you think others want to hear.
biases.example: You might agree with a group even if you don't really.

biases.summary: You have trouble telling faces of other races apart.
biases.example: It might be harder for you to recognize people of a different race.

biases.summary: Experts think everyone knows what they know.
biases.example: A teacher might forget what it's like to not understand a basic concept.

biases.summary: You blame victims for bad things that happen to them so you feel safer.
biases.example: If someone gets robbed, you might think they were careless.

biases.summary: People who are bad at something think they are good, and experts doubt themselves.
biases.example: Someone who doesn't know much about a topic might act like they are an expert.

biases.summary: You think your own views are the most important.
biases.example: You might think everyone sees the world the same way you do.

biases.summary: You think others do things for rewards, but you do them because you like to.
biases.example: You might think a coworker is only working hard for a promotion.

biases.summary: You think more people agree with you than they actually do.
biases.example: If you like a certain TV show, you might think most of your friends like it too.

biases.summary: You think your skills and projects are more special than they are.
biases.example: You might think your ideas are very original.

biases.summary: You blame people's personality for their actions and not the situation.
biases.example: If someone cuts you off in traffic, you might think they are a bad person.

biases.summary: You have unfair beliefs about people based on their gender.
biases.example: You might assume a nurse is a woman and a doctor is a man.

biases.summary: You think one person's traits in a group apply to the whole group.
biases.example: You might think everyone in a certain club is the same way as one member you met.

biases.summary: A group makes bad decisions because they want to agree with each other.
biases.example: A team might go along with a bad idea to avoid arguments.

biases.summary: Group discussions can make people's opinions more extreme.
biases.example: After talking about something, a group might have stronger opinions than they did at first.

biases.summary: If you like one thing about someone, you'll like everything about them.
biases.example: You might think a good-looking person is also smart and kind.

biases.summary: You are more likely to help one person you can see than a large group.
biases.example: People often donate more to help one sick child than to a large charity.

biases.summary: You think you know others better than they know you.
biases.example: You might think you understand your friend's reasons better than they do.

biases.summary: You think others know what you are feeling.
biases.example: You might think people can tell you are nervous even if you are hiding it well.

biases.summary: You think you are better than average.
biases.example: You might think you are a better driver than most people.

biases.summary: You have unconscious connections between ideas.
biases.example: You might unconsciously link certain groups of people with certain jobs.

biases.summary: You have unconscious beliefs about groups of people.
biases.example: You might unconsciously think that people from a certain place are all the same.

biases.summary: You doubt your success and fear being seen as a fake.
biases.example: You might feel like you are not good enough even though you are successful.

biases.summary: You favor people who are in your own group.
biases.example: You might be nicer to people who like the same sports team as you.

biases.summary: You think people's actions are on purpose rather than accidents.
biases.example: If someone bumps into you, you might think they did it on purpose.

biases.summary: You believe a message more if you like or trust the person telling it.
biases.example: You might trust health advice from a doctor you like.

biases.summary: After doing something good, you might feel like you can do something bad.
biases.example: Someone who donates to charity might then feel okay about being a little selfish.

biases.summary: You are judged for things you can't control.
biases.example: Someone might be praised for saving someone in a flood even if it was mostly luck.

biases.summary: You think others are more selfish than they really are.
biases.example: You might think people only help others because they want something in return.

biases.summary: You think you see the world as it really is and that others are wrong if they disagree.
biases.example: You might think your political views are just the facts.

biases.summary: You don't want to use ideas or products from outside your own group.
biases.example: A company might not want to use a good idea from another company.

biases.summary: People act differently when they know they are being watched.
biases.example: Students might do better on a test if they know someone is watching.

biases.summary: You think people in other groups are all the same.
biases.example: You might think everyone from another country is alike.

biases.summary: You favor people who are not in your own group.
biases.example: You might think people from a more famous school are better than people from your school.

biases.summary: You think your private beliefs are different from what most people publicly say.
biases.example: Students might not ask questions in class even if they are confused because they think everyone else understands.

biases.summary: You have a negative opinion about someone without a good reason.
biases.example: You might dislike someone just because they are from a certain group.

biases.summary: You think others have the same beliefs and feelings as you do.
biases.example: If you love a certain food, you might think everyone else loves it too.

biases.summary: Higher expectations can lead to better performance.
biases.example: Teachers who think certain students are smart might help them do better.

biases.summary: You dislike ideas just because they come from someone you don't like.
biases.example: You might reject a suggestion just because it came from someone you disagree with.

biases.summary: You answer questions in a way that makes you look good.
biases.example: You might say you eat healthier than you really do on a survey.

biases.summary: You say the opposite of what you want someone to do so they will do what you want.
biases.example: You might tell a child 'Don't eat all your vegetables!' hoping they will.

biases.summary: You see yourself as a victim more easily than as someone who causes problems.
biases.example: In an argument, you might focus on how you were hurt more than your own actions.

biases.summary: You blame your failures on others but take credit for your successes.
biases.example: You might say you did well on a test because you are smart but did badly because the test was unfair.

biases.summary: Men tend to think women are more interested in them than they really are.
biases.example: A man might think a woman smiling at him means she likes him romantically.

biases.summary: Women tend to think men are less interested in them than they really are.
biases.example: A woman might not realize a man is flirting with her.

biases.summary: Groups talk more about what everyone knows than what only some people know.
biases.example: A team might spend more time on common knowledge during a meeting.

biases.summary: You compare people only to others in the same group.
biases.example: A good job applicant might not get hired if compared to an even better one in the same group of applicants.

biases.summary: You answer questions in a way that makes you look good to others.
biases.example: You might say you exercise more than you really do.

biases.summary: You think people notice you more than they actually do.
biases.example: You might worry about a small mistake because you think everyone saw it.

biases.summary: You have unfair beliefs about groups of people that you apply to individuals.
biases.example: You might think all teenagers are rebellious.

biases.summary: You expect people in a group to be a certain way without knowing them.
biases.example: You might assume someone from a certain region has a certain accent.

biases.summary: You think media affects others more than it affects you.
biases.example: You might think ads influence other people but not you.

biases.summary: You see yourself as complex but others as simple.
biases.example: You might think your own actions depend on the situation but others' actions just show their personality.

biases.summary: People with autism can have amazing skills in some areas but struggle in others.
biases.example: Someone with autism might be great at math but have trouble making friends.

biases.summary: You blame bad things done by other groups on their nature and good things on luck.
biases.example: You might say a bad thing done by another political party shows they are bad, but a good thing was just luck.

biases.summary: You think you are worse than others at hard tasks.
biases.example: You might think you are not as good as others at a difficult game.

biases.summary: You tend to think women have more good qualities than men.
biases.example: You might automatically think women are more caring.

biases.summary: Forgetting things happens when you don't pay enough attention when learning or remembering.
biases.example: You forget where you put your phone because you were thinking about something else.

biases.summary: After learning something new, you suddenly see it everywhere.
biases.example: You learn a new word and then start hearing it all the time.

biases.summary: You remember strange things more easily.
biases.example: You are more likely to remember a weird image than a normal one.

biases.summary: You remember seeing more of a scene than you actually did.
biases.example: After seeing a picture of a cat in a doorway, you might remember seeing more of the room.

biases.summary: Adults can't remember events from when they were very young.
biases.example: You probably don't remember your first birthday party.

biases.summary: You remember your choices as better than they were.
biases.example: After picking a certain phone, you might think it's better than it really is.

biases.summary: Your sense of time can change.
biases.example: Time might feel like it's going by very slowly when you are bored.

biases.summary: You remember things better when they are grouped together.
biases.example: You remember a phone number by breaking it into smaller parts.

biases.summary: You make up memories without meaning to.
biases.example: Someone with memory loss might create stories about the past.

biases.summary: You remember your past self as being more like your present self.
biases.example: You might think you always liked the same things you like now.

biases.summary: You think a memory or idea is yours when it's really from somewhere else.
biases.example: You might think of a song and not realize you heard it before.

biases.summary: You can't remember something because you are in a different place or situation.
biases.example: You might forget something you learned in school when you are at home.

biases.summary: You remember how an event felt at its worst and at the end, not how long it lasted.
biases.example: You might remember a painful shot based on the worst part and the end, not the whole time.

biases.summary: You think you have changed a lot in the past but won't change much in the future.
biases.example: Someone in their 30s might think their personality is now set.

biases.summary: You remember past events as happier than they really were.
biases.example: You might remember a vacation as perfect, forgetting any problems.

biases.summary: Bad memories fade faster than good memories.
biases.example: Over time, you might remember a past trip as better than it actually was.

biases.summary: You remember things that never happened or remember them wrong.
biases.example: You might think you saw something that you only heard about.

biases.summary: You remember things better if you come up with them yourself.
biases.example: You might remember a definition better if you try to explain it in your own words.

biases.summary: Men and women might remember details of events differently.
biases.example: Studies suggest women might remember more details than men.

biases.summary: You forget information you can easily find online.
biases.example: You might not remember a fact because you know you can just look it up.

biases.summary: You remember past experiences as better than they were.
biases.example: You might remember a past party as amazing, forgetting any bad parts.

biases.summary: After something happens, you think you knew it all along.
biases.example: After a game, you might say you knew who was going to win.

biases.summary: You remember funny things more easily.
biases.example: You are more likely to remember a funny ad.

biases.summary: You remember things better when you learn them over time instead of all at once.
biases.example: Studying a little bit each day is better than cramming all night.

biases.summary: When you tell a story, some details get lost and others become more important.
biases.example: A story might get shorter and more exciting each time it's told.

biases.summary: You remember shorter lists better than longer lists.
biases.example: You are more likely to remember a short grocery list.

biases.summary: You can usually only remember about 5 to 9 things at once in your short-term memory.
biases.example: Most people can only remember a short string of numbers.

biases.summary: You like things more just because you are familiar with them.
biases.example: You might start to like a song more after hearing it many times.

biases.summary: You remember things by imagining them in familiar places.
biases.example: You might remember a shopping list by picturing each item in a different room of your house.

biases.summary: You remember something but forget where you learned it.
biases.example: You might think you heard something from a friend when you actually read it online.

biases.summary: Wrong information can change your memory of an event.
biases.example: If someone asks you questions that suggest something happened, you might start to remember it that way.

biases.summary: You remember the last things you hear better than the last things you read.
biases.example: You might remember the end of a spoken list better than the end of a written list.

biases.summary: You remember things that match your current mood.
biases.example: If you are happy, you might remember happy memories.

biases.summary: You remember bad things more than good things.
biases.example: You might remember one bad comment more than many good ones.

biases.summary: You don't remember what the person before you said.
biases.example: If you are about to speak, you might not remember the person who just finished talking.

biases.summary: You have fond memories of the past.
biases.example: You might really like songs from when you were a teenager.

biases.summary: Seeing some items on a list makes it harder to remember the rest.
biases.example: If you see a few words from a list you studied, you might have trouble remembering the other words.

biases.summary: You remember an experience by its best/worst part and how it ended.
biases.example: You might remember a trip by the best thing that happened and how you felt at the end.

biases.summary: Upsetting memories keep coming back.
biases.example: Someone who went through something scary might keep having flashbacks.

biases.summary: You remember pictures better than words.
biases.example: You might remember information better if it has pictures.

biases.summary: Older people tend to remember more good things than bad things.
biases.example: An older person might remember happy times from the past more easily.

biases.summary: You remember the first things on a list better.
biases.example: You might remember the first few items on a shopping list.

biases.summary: You remember things better if they are harder to understand at first.
biases.example: You might remember a complex article better than a simple one.

biases.summary: You remember the last things on a list better.
biases.example: You might remember the last few items on a shopping list you just read.

biases.summary: You think a word or phrase is new when it's actually been around for a while.
biases.example: You might suddenly notice a certain type of car everywhere after you just learned about it.

biases.summary: It's easier to recognize information than to remember it on your own.
biases.example: You might not remember a name but will recognize it from a list.

biases.summary: Older adults remember events from their teens and early twenties more clearly.
biases.example: An elderly person might have strong memories from when they were young.

biases.summary: You might not see a word if it is repeated quickly.
biases.example: You might read a sentence with a repeated word and not notice it.

biases.summary: You remember the past as better than it was.
biases.example: You might look back on a hard trip with only good memories.

biases.summary: You think your past attitudes are the same as your current ones.
biases.example: You might remember always liking the same political party you like now.

biases.summary: You remember things better when they relate to you.
biases.example: You might remember a fact if it's about something you are interested in.

biases.summary: You remember the first and last things on a list best.
biases.example: You might remember the first and last names on a list of people.

biases.summary: You try to remember things in the order you heard them.
biases.example: You might repeat a phone number in the order you heard it.

biases.summary: You remember a memory but mix up where it came from.
biases.example: You might think you learned something from a movie when you read it in a book.

biases.summary: You learn better when you study over time.
biases.example: Studying a little each day is better than studying all at once.

biases.summary: You remember lessons better if they are told as a story.
biases.example: You might remember a lesson better if it's told as a story.

biases.summary: You remember details better than general ideas in a structure.
biases.example: You might remember specific tasks in a project better than the overall goals.

biases.summary: You have trouble remembering the end of a spoken list if something is said after it.
biases.example: You might forget the last few words of a list if someone says 'okay' at the end.

biases.summary: Time seems to slow down when you are scared.
biases.example: During a car accident, time might feel like it's moving very slowly.

biases.summary: You remember recent events as further in the past and past events as closer.
biases.example: You might think something that happened a few years ago happened more recently.

biases.summary: You remember things better if you test yourself on them.
biases.example: Taking practice quizzes can help you remember information for a test.

biases.summary: You know a word but can't quite remember it.
biases.example: You might struggle to recall a familiar name.

biases.summary: You remember the general idea better than the exact words.
biases.example: You might remember what a conversation was about but not the exact words used.

biases.summary: You remember things that stand out from the rest.
biases.example: You are more likely to remember a word that is a different color on a list.

biases.summary: You think familiar trips take less time than they do.
biases.example: You might underestimate how long your usual drive to work takes.

biases.summary: You remember unfinished tasks better than finished ones.
biases.example: You might remember the details of a task you were interrupted from doing.

biases.summary: You tend to think something is alive or has a plan, even if it doesn't.
biases.example: You hear a noise in the dark and think it's an animal.

biases.summary: You believe stories or single examples more than facts or numbers.
biases.example: You say a certain food is bad for you because your friend got sick after eating it, even if most people are fine.

biases.summary: You see the world only from a human point of view.
biases.example: You think animals feel things exactly like people do.

biases.summary: You think new ideas are better just because they are new.
biases.example: A company uses a new technology just because it's new, not because it's better.

biases.summary: You think something will happen just because it could happen.
biases.example: You might not study because you think you'll probably guess the answers right anyway.

biases.summary: You see connections between things that are not related.
biases.example: You see shapes in the clouds.

biases.summary: You think something is wrong because the argument for it was bad.
biases.example: You might think exercise isn't good for you because someone made a silly argument for it.

biases.summary: You answer an easy question instead of a hard one without realizing it.
biases.example: When asked how happy you are, you might just think about how your day is going.

biases.summary: A belief becomes stronger as it's repeated more in the news and by people.
biases.example: A small health scare might become a big worry because everyone is talking about it.

biases.summary: When someone proves you wrong, you believe your original idea even more.
biases.example: If someone shows you facts that go against your beliefs, you might hold onto your beliefs even stronger.

biases.summary: You think general personality descriptions are made just for you.
biases.example: You might think a horoscope is very accurate for you even though it's true for many people.

biases.summary: You focus on specific details and ignore general facts.
biases.example: When a test result is positive for a rare disease, you might think you definitely have it, even though it's unlikely.

biases.summary: You judge how good an argument is by whether you agree with the conclusion.
biases.example: You might agree with a weak argument if you like the outcome.

biases.summary: When looking at a limited group, things can seem related when they are not in general.
biases.example: In a hospital, two unrelated illnesses might seem connected because you only see sick people.

biases.summary: Grouping data too broadly can hide important differences.
biases.example: Saying all students are doing the same based on average scores.

biases.summary: You see patterns in things that happen randomly.
biases.example: You might think a series of coin flips has a pattern even though it's random.

biases.summary: You feel uneasy when your actions don't match your beliefs.
biases.example: Someone who knows smoking is bad might still smoke and feel conflicted.

biases.summary: You treat information from the same source as if it's from different sources.
biases.example: Thinking multiple studies by the same group give more proof than they really do.

biases.summary: You think specific events are more likely than general ones.
biases.example: You might think someone is more likely to be a nurse and a mother than just a nurse.

biases.summary: You are slow to change your beliefs when new evidence comes out.
biases.example: You might not update your opinion even after seeing new facts.

biases.summary: You still believe wrong information even after it has been corrected.
biases.example: You might still think a false news story is true even after reading a correction.

biases.summary: You think things were better in the past and are getting worse.
biases.example: You might say that music today is not as good as it used to be.

biases.summary: You think good things are more likely to happen to you.
biases.example: You might believe you will easily get your dream job.

biases.summary: You believe things have a true, hidden nature.
biases.example: You might think all people from a certain country are a certain way.

biases.summary: You expect things to be more extreme than they usually are.
biases.example: You might think a small investment will quickly make you rich.

biases.summary: Researchers see what they expect to see in their experiments.
biases.example: A scientist might accidentally make their study results match what they thought would happen.

biases.summary: You think things that look alike work alike.
biases.example: You might think two medicines with similar packaging do the same thing.

biases.summary: You think knowing about a problem is enough to fix it.
biases.example: You might think just knowing the risks of smoking will make you quit.

biases.summary: You think past random events affect future random events.
biases.example: If a coin has landed on heads many times, you might think it's more likely to land on tails next.

biases.summary: You are too sure about easy tasks and not sure enough about hard tasks.
biases.example: You might think a simple puzzle is very easy but doubt your ability to solve a hard one.

biases.summary: You think someone who has been lucky will continue to be lucky.
biases.example: You might think a basketball player who made a few shots in a row will make the next one.

biases.summary: You feel like your actions are caused by something outside of you.
biases.example: Someone using a Ouija board might feel like something else is moving their hands.

biases.summary: You think you understand things until you have to explain them.
biases.example: You might think you know how a toilet works until someone asks you to explain it.

biases.summary: You are too sure about your judgments, especially if the information seems to fit.
biases.example: You might feel very sure about a stock pick based on a few good signs.

biases.summary: You think two things are related when they are not.
biases.example: You might think that wearing a lucky shirt helps you win games.

biases.summary: You believe things are true if you hear them many times.
biases.example: You might start to believe a false story if you see it shared online a lot.

biases.summary: You don't pay enough attention to how many people were studied.
biases.example: You might believe a study based on a few people as much as one based on many.

biases.summary: You think good things happen to good people and bad things to bad people.
biases.example: If someone has bad luck, you might think they deserved it.

biases.summary: You think if you don't know if two things are the same, then they must be different.
biases.example: You might not recognize a robber in a mask even if you saw them without the mask later.

biases.summary: You think about money in terms of numbers, not what it can really buy.
biases.example: You might feel richer after a raise without thinking about whether things cost more now.

biases.summary: If something can go wrong, it will.
biases.example: Expecting the worst to happen.

biases.summary: You create stories to explain random events.
biases.example: You might make up a story about why a company succeeded.

biases.summary: You ignore how likely something is when you are worried about it.
biases.example: You might be very afraid of flying even though it's very unlikely to crash.

biases.summary: You underestimate the chance of bad things happening.
biases.example: Someone in an area that gets earthquakes might not prepare because they think it won't happen to them.

biases.summary: You think your own judgments are not biased.
biases.example: You might think your opinions are based only on facts.

biases.summary: Researchers can unintentionally make participants do what they expect.
biases.example: A scientist might accidentally influence people in a study to get the results they want.

biases.summary: The simplest explanation is usually the best.
biases.example: When trying to figure out why something happened, the easiest answer is often right.

biases.summary: You think good things are more likely to happen to you than bad things.
biases.example: You might think you are less likely to get sick than other people.

biases.summary: You are too sure about your answers.
biases.example: You might be very certain you know the answer to a question even if you are wrong.

biases.summary: You see faces or patterns in random things.
biases.example: Seeing a face in a cloud.

biases.summary: You think bad things are more likely to happen.
biases.example: You might always worry about bad things happening to you.

biases.summary: You don't notice plants around you or think they are important.
biases.example: You might focus on animals in a forest and not really see the plants.

biases.summary: You feel better because you think you are getting treatment, even if you are not.
biases.example: A fake pill can sometimes make people feel better.

biases.summary: Seeing or hearing something can affect how you respond to other things.
biases.example: Seeing the color yellow might make you think of a banana faster.

biases.summary: You are too excited about new inventions and don't see their problems.
biases.example: A company might be too eager to use a new technology without thinking about the downsides.

biases.summary: You think big events must have big causes.
biases.example: You might think a major disaster must have a huge, complicated reason.

biases.summary: Studies with positive results are more likely to be published.
biases.example: You might only see studies that show a treatment works, not the ones that show it doesn't.

biases.summary: You judge things more harshly than needed.
biases.example: You might get very upset about a small mistake someone makes.

biases.summary: You trust numbers more than words.
biases.example: You might believe statistics more than personal stories.

biases.summary: You judge things based on how similar they are to a typical example.
biases.example: You might think a quiet person who likes books is a librarian.

biases.summary: You believe things that rhyme are more true.
biases.example: 'An apple a day keeps the doctor away' might seem more believable because it rhymes.

biases.summary: You start to believe what you say.
biases.example: After saying you like something, you might start to like it more.

biases.summary: You don't think about the size of a problem when deciding how much to care.
biases.example: You might be willing to help a small number of people as much as a large number.

biases.summary: You see what you expect to see.
biases.example: If you are looking for a certain car, you might notice it more often.

biases.summary: You reject new ideas that go against what you already believe.
biases.example: Scientists might ignore new findings that disagree with their current theories.

biases.summary: You think the chance of separate events is higher than the chance of them all happening.
biases.example: You might think you are more likely to die from heart disease or cancer than from any cause.

biases.summary: You believe something is true if it has personal meaning to you.
biases.example: You might believe a vague fortune telling because you can relate it to your life.

biases.summary: You only see the winners and not the losers.
biases.example: You might think starting a business is easy because you only see the successful ones.

biases.summary: You mix up what causes what.
biases.example: You might think swimming makes you thin, but thin people might just be more likely to swim.

biases.summary: You defend the way things are, even if they are unfair.
biases.example: You might say that the current rules are good even if they hurt some people.

biases.summary: You think things are the way they are for a reason or plan.
biases.example: You might think natural disasters happen to teach us something.

biases.summary: You tend to believe what people say.
biases.example: You might believe a statement at first without questioning it.

biases.summary: You think things will keep going well just before something bad happens.
biases.example: Someone might feel very safe right before a big change that hurts them.

biases.summary: How you choose a group to study can affect the results.
biases.example: Survey results might be wrong if certain types of people don't answer.

biases.summary: A group makes a decision that no individual member wants, but all agree to avoid conflict.
biases.example: A family goes to a restaurant no one really likes because they all thought everyone else wanted to go.

biases.summary: Modifying an argument or theory to prevent it from being falsified.
biases.example: Claiming that a diet failed because the person didn't *truly* commit, rather than the diet itself being flawed.

biases.summary: Incorrectly predicting how one will feel in the future.
biases.example: Believing winning the lottery will bring perpetual happiness, or that a breakup will lead to endless despair.

biases.summary: A metaphorical illustration of how people are unwilling to accept new truths.
biases.example: People in a society clinging to traditional beliefs despite clear evidence of a different reality.

biases.summary: Viewing situations in extreme, black-and-white terms.
biases.example: If you don't get a perfect score, you consider yourself a complete failure.

biases.summary: Failing to consider alternative possibilities or solutions.
biases.example: Focusing only on one career path without exploring other viable options.

biases.summary: Assuming something is true because it hasn't been proven false (or vice versa).
biases.example: No one has proven ghosts don't exist, so they must be real.

biases.summary: Overestimating the likelihood of positive events and underestimating negative ones.
biases.example: Believing you're more likely to win the lottery than to be in a car accident.

biases.summary: Uncertainty about the cause of others' behaviors or one's own outcomes.
biases.example: A minority employee wondering if positive feedback is due to their work or a diversity initiative.

biases.summary: Distinct patterns of information processing observed in individuals with ASD, leading to specific cognitive biases.
biases.example: Individuals with ASD might exhibit reduced susceptibility to certain social biases like the bandwagon effect due to different social processing.

biases.summary: Mistaking how easily something comes to mind for how common or likely it is.
biases.example: Fearing shark attacks more than vending machine accidents because shark attacks are more sensationalized in media.

biases.summary: People generally believe that the world is fair and people get what they deserve.
biases.example: Blaming a homeless person for their situation, assuming they must have done something to deserve it.

biases.summary: Humor arises when something is perceived as a violation (e.g., threatening, absurd) but also benign (safe, acceptable).
biases.example: A playful tease between friends that is mildly offensive but not truly hurtful.

biases.summary: A narrow or limited way of thinking, preventing consideration of broader perspectives.
biases.example: An engineer only considering technical solutions to a problem, ignoring social or ethical implications.

biases.summary: Failing to act or react to a gradually worsening situation until it's too late.
biases.example: A company slowly losing market share but not changing strategy until it's on the verge of bankruptcy.

biases.summary: Decision-making is limited by the information available, cognitive limitations, and time constraints.
biases.example: Choosing the 'good enough' option for a purchase rather than exhaustive research to find the absolute best.

biases.summary: Individuals are less likely to offer help to a victim when other people are present.
biases.example: No one calls for help when a person collapses in a crowded public place, assuming someone else will.

biases.summary: Impairments in recognizing or naming objects from specific categories (e.g., living vs. non-living).
biases.example: A brain injury patient who can identify tools but not animals.

biases.summary: Incorrectly identifying the cause of an event.
biases.example: Assuming that because event B happened after event A, A must have caused B.

biases.summary: Selecting only evidence that supports one's position while ignoring contradictory evidence.
biases.example: A politician quoting only statistics that favor their policy, disregarding data that shows negative effects.

biases.summary: Having too many options makes decision-making difficult and can lead to dissatisfaction.
biases.example: Feeling overwhelmed and buying nothing when faced with an aisle of 50 different jams.

biases.summary: Dismissing past ideas or practices as inferior simply because they are old.
biases.example: Rejecting a traditional medical remedy as useless because it's not a modern pharmaceutical.

biases.summary: Tendency to prefer information that is easy to process and understand.
biases.example: Choosing a simple, familiar product over a complex, potentially better one.

biases.summary: A belief or idea becomes more ingrained as it is repeatedly affirmed by a community.
biases.example: A conspiracy theory gaining widespread acceptance within a specific online forum.

biases.summary: Seeking out, interpreting, and remembering information in a way that confirms one's existing beliefs.
biases.example: Only reading news articles that support your political views and dismissing those that don't.

biases.summary: Similar to confirmation bias, focusing on information that supports a hypothesis.
biases.example: A detective looking only for evidence that confirms their initial suspect, ignoring other leads.

biases.summary: Only testing hypotheses that are consistent with one's existing beliefs.
biases.example: A scientist designing an experiment in a way that is most likely to confirm their theory.

biases.summary: Slowness to change one's belief in response to new evidence, even when statistically warranted.
biases.example: A doctor being slow to adopt a new treatment even after strong evidence of its effectiveness.

biases.summary: Individual differences in the extent to which people consider potential future outcomes of their current behaviors.
biases.example: A person with low CFC might prioritize immediate gratification over long-term health goals.

biases.summary: Feeling compelled to maintain consistency with prior statements or actions, even if illogical.
biases.example: Continuing to argue a point in a debate even after realizing you're wrong because you've already committed to the position.

biases.summary: The greater the psychological distance to an event, the more abstractly it is construed.
biases.example: When planning a distant vacation, you focus on broad, desirable aspects (relaxation), but as it approaches, you focus on concrete details (packing, airport).

biases.summary: Belief that objects or people can transmit properties to others through contact.
biases.example: Refusing to wear a sweater that belonged to a murderer, even if it's been cleaned.

biases.summary: Overestimating one's ability to control outcomes.
biases.example: Feeling that shaking the dice harder will increase the chances of rolling a six.

biases.summary: Believing that one can succeed solely through individual effort, disregarding systemic factors or collaboration.
biases.example: A new startup founder insisting on doing everything themselves, refusing to delegate or seek external help.

biases.summary: Judging information based on the perceived credibility of the source, rather than the content itself.
biases.example: Dismissing a scientific study because it's published by an organization you distrust, regardless of the research quality.

biases.summary: Interpreting and judging phenomena by standards inherent to one's own culture.
biases.example: Assuming that a certain social custom in another country is 'wrong' because it differs from your own.

biases.summary: In auctions, the winning bidder often pays more than the asset is worth, due to overestimating its value.
biases.example: A company overpaying for an acquisition in a competitive bidding process.

biases.summary: Finding spurious patterns in data by looking for enough combinations of variables.
biases.example: Discovering a correlation between ice cream sales and shark attacks, and concluding that ice cream causes shark attacks.

biases.summary: Loss of self-awareness and self-restraint in group situations that foster anonymity and arousal.
biases.example: People engaging in destructive behavior during a riot, feeling less accountable for their actions.

biases.summary: Prejudice or discrimination against people with disabilities.
biases.example: Assuming a person in a wheelchair is incapable of performing a certain job function.

biases.summary: Highly competent individuals underestimate their abilities and may feel like impostors.
biases.example: An accomplished expert feeling they are not good enough despite widespread recognition.

biases.summary: Inferring individual characteristics from statistics about the group to which that individual belongs.
biases.example: Assuming a specific student is lazy because the average GPA of their university is low.

biases.summary: Recalling past events in a way that makes oneself appear more central or influential than they actually were.
biases.example: Remembering a group project as if you did most of the work, even if it was a shared effort.

biases.summary: The idea that cognitive processes are deeply rooted in the body's interactions with the world.
biases.example: Holding a warm drink makes people perceive others as more generous.

biases.summary: Using a word or phrase with two different meanings in an argument, leading to a misleading conclusion.
biases.example: Claiming that 'all men are mortal, and no woman is a man, therefore no woman is mortal' (using 'man' in two different senses).

biases.summary: Evaluating other cultures based on preconceptions originating in the standards and customs of one's own culture.
biases.example: Believing your country's way of life is inherently superior to all others.

biases.summary: Deliberately ignoring or suppressing evidence that contradicts one's beliefs or desired outcome.
biases.example: A pharmaceutical company hiding unfavorable results from drug trials.

biases.summary: Overstating or misrepresenting the extent or significance of something.
biases.example: Claiming that a small inconvenience is 'the worst thing that ever happened.'

biases.summary: Believing that one's own group, nation, or species is unique and superior.
biases.example: A country believing it has a special destiny or moral authority above other nations.

biases.summary: Feeling guilt about one's advantages or privileges compared to others.
biases.example: Feeling guilty about enjoying a good meal while others are starving.

biases.summary: Experts can sometimes be less effective at solving problems outside their narrow domain of expertise.
biases.example: A renowned heart surgeon struggling to diagnose a simple skin rash.

biases.summary: Presenting only two options as if they are the only possibilities, when more options exist.
biases.example: Saying 'Either you're with us, or you're with the terrorists' when there are many nuanced positions.

biases.summary: Belief that all events are predetermined and therefore inevitable.
biases.example: Refusing to take preventative health measures because 'what will be, will be.'

biases.summary: Anxiety that an exciting or interesting event may currently be happening elsewhere, often fueled by social media.
biases.example: Attending a party you don't really want to go to because you see friends posting about it online.

biases.summary: Interpreting figurative language literally, leading to miscommunication.
biases.example: Taking the phrase 'it's raining cats and dogs' to mean actual animals are falling from the sky.

biases.summary: Belief that one's abilities are fixed traits and cannot be developed.
biases.example: Avoiding challenging tasks because you believe your intelligence is limited.

biases.summary: Being overly reliant on a specific tool or method, even when it's inefficient.
biases.example: Always using a hammer to fix something, even when a screwdriver is clearly more appropriate.

biases.summary: Believing that a series of successes makes continued success less likely.
biases.example: A basketball team that's won many games in a row expecting to lose the next one because 'their luck will run out.'

biases.summary: Drawing a broad conclusion based on a small or unrepresentative sample.
biases.example: Meeting one rude person from a city and concluding that all people from that city are rude.

biases.summary: Assuming that the truth lies in the middle of two opposing arguments.
biases.example: Believing that the best solution to a complex issue is always a compromise between two extremes.

biases.summary: Attributing positive outcomes to one's own group and negative outcomes to external factors.
biases.example: A sports team attributing their win to their skill but a loss to bad refereeing.

biases.summary: Making assumptions about a whole group or range of cases based on an inadequate sample.
biases.example: Concluding that all fast food is unhealthy after eating one bad burger.

biases.summary: Tendency to interpret ambiguous social cues as hostile or aggressive.
biases.example: Reacting angrily to an accidental bump in a crowd, believing it was an intentional shove.

biases.summary: A systematic distortion of reasoning or judgment due to strong adherence to a particular ideology.
biases.example: Interpreting all economic data through the lens of a specific political theory, ignoring contradictory evidence.

biases.summary: Believing that external validation (e.g., praise, awards) is the primary measure of one's worth.
biases.example: Feeling worthless if you don't receive public recognition for your efforts, even if you achieved your goals.

biases.summary: Asserting two or more contradictory statements.
biases.example: Claiming to be a strong advocate for free speech while also demanding censorship of opposing views.

biases.summary: Introducing an irrelevant topic to divert attention from the original issue.
biases.example: When discussing the safety of a new car, bringing up its beautiful color to distract from the crash test ratings.

biases.summary: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
biases.example: After someone says, 'We should invest more in public transit,' their opponent retorts, 'So you want to take away everyone's cars and force them onto buses?'

biases.summary: Arguing that a small first step will inevitably lead to a chain of negative events without sufficient evidence.
biases.example: 'If we allow children to choose their bedtime, soon they'll be choosing not to go to school at all.'

biases.summary: Making a universal claim and then excluding counterexamples by arbitrarily redefining the criteria.
biases.example: Person A: 'No Scotsman puts sugar on his porridge.' Person B: 'But my uncle Angus is a Scotsman and he puts sugar on his porridge.' Person A: 'Ah, but no *true* Scotsman puts sugar on his porridge.'

biases.summary: Judging something based on its origin or source rather than its current meaning or context.
biases.example: Dismissing a new medical treatment because it was developed by a company with a history of past controversies.

biases.summary: Manipulating an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.
biases.example: A political ad showing sad puppies in a shelter to argue for a policy that has no connection to animal welfare.

biases.summary: Insisting that a claim is true simply because an authority figure said it, without other supporting evidence.
biases.example: A celebrity endorses a diet plan, and people follow it assuming it's effective, despite a lack of scientific evidence.

biases.summary: Arguing that because something is difficult to understand, it must be untrue.
biases.example: Saying you can't imagine how evolution could be true, so it must be false.

biases.summary: Cherry-picking data clusters to fit a presumption, ignoring the differences and focusing on the similarities.
biases.example: An anti-vaccine advocate points to a cluster of autism cases in a specific town with high vaccination rates, ignoring all the towns with high vaccination rates and no such cluster.

biases.summary: Demanding more and more evidence or changing the criteria for success after an opponent has met the initial challenge.
biases.example: First asking for proof that a new policy works, then when presented with proof, saying 'but it needs to work for ten years straight before I'll believe it'.

biases.summary: Arguing that something is good because it's 'natural' or bad because it's 'unnatural'.
biases.example: Claiming that herbal remedies are always safer than synthetic drugs because they come from plants.

biases.summary: A fallacy in which the premise of an argument presupposes the truth of its conclusion.
biases.example: 'This plan is the best one because it is superior to all other plans.'

biases.summary: Attacking your opponent's character or personal traits in an attempt to undermine their argument.
biases.example: Instead of debating a scientist's climate change research, you say, 'Of course you'd say that, you're just trying to get more grant money.'

biases.summary: The tendency to stick with one's current way of thinking, even when faced with new information that contradicts it.
biases.example: A manager continues to use an outdated software system despite employees showing that a new system is far more efficient.

biases.summary: The tendency to feel and express emotions similar to and influenced by those of others.
biases.example: One person in an office starts panicking about a deadline, and soon the entire team feels anxious and stressed.

biases.summary: Failing to see visible objects when our attention is directed elsewhere.
biases.example: While counting basketball passes between players in a video, you fail to notice a person in a gorilla suit walking through the middle of the scene.

biases.summary: The tendency to seek information when it does not affect action or decisions.
biases.example: Spending hours researching the subtle differences between two nearly identical cameras, even though both are more than sufficient for your needs and the extra information won't change your choice.

biases.summary: Applying standards, principles, or rules to other people or circumstances, while making oneself or one's own circumstances exempt from the same rules without providing adequate justification.
biases.example: Claiming that your business's tax loopholes are 'smart incentives' while insisting that loopholes for others are 'unfair tax evasion'.

biases.summary: Viewing the world in absolute, black-and-white categories, with no shades of gray.
biases.example: Believing that people are either 'good' or 'evil' with no capacity for both positive and negative traits.

biases.summary: The error of assuming that one's own subjective perspective and way of seeing the world is an objective property of the world itself.
biases.example: Assuming that because you find a particular painting beautiful, its beauty is an objective fact that everyone should be able to see.
